summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 between FBI agents, a U.S. Attorney's Office representative, and a U.S. Marshal discussing Jeffrey Epstein's potential violation of International Megan's Law by failing to report international travel. The emails coordinate investigative efforts and share information about unreported trips to Austria and Morocco, and discuss strategies to identify victims from the Caribbean region.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of investigation, registered sex offender
persons.context: The central subject of the email chain; being investigated for potential International Megan's Law violations for failing to report travel to Austria and Morocco in 2019.

events.title: Epstein signs IML travel reporting form
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed the Virgin Islands sex offender registry Notification of Duty to Report Travel (International Megan's Law) form.

events.title: Unreported travel to Vienna, Austria
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein traveled to Vienna, Austria with three female passengers, where they went for coffee. This travel appears not to have been reported as required by International Megan's Law.

events.title: Unreported travel to Morocco
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein traveled to Morocco. This travel appears not to have been reported as required by International Megan's Law.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was under active FBI investigation nationwide as of July 2019.

Epstein failed to report international travel to Austria (March 22, 2019) and Morocco (April 25, 2019) as required by International Megan's Law after signing the travel reporting form on March 15, 2019.
Law enforcement was concerned that making this information public might hamper the ongoing investigation, especially given Epstein's resources.
Investigators were seeking ways to identify potential victims from the Caribbean, Puerto Rico, and Dominican Republic who may have visited Epstein's St. Thomas compound.
The emails show coordination between the FBI, U.S. Attorney's Office, and U.S. Marshals Service regarding the Epstein investigation.
